expense.name: Moses basket/crib
expense.reviewtext:
We've included:
  • Moses basket with a stand or a crib with a mattress : from £40 to £300
  • Linen : from £20 to £60

Remember that babies grow quickly so they won't be in a basket or crib for long, so it may be cheaper to go straight for a cot.

Use the slider to choose a level of spend, from budget to luxury. We'll work out the total cost based on your choices.

The costs are only a guide based on our own research. You may be able to find things more cheaply, or you may want things that we haven't included.

expense.name: Cot
expense.reviewtext:
We've included:
  • Standard cot or cot bed : from £60 to £400
  • Cot mattress : from £15 to £200
  • Cot linen and bedding : from £20 to £100

Even if you have a cot already, you may still want to buy a new mattress.

You might find that buying a 'starter set' of cot linen works out cheaper than buying sheets, blankets and bumpers separately, so check them out.

Use the slider to choose a level of spend, from budget to luxury. We' ll work out the total cost based on your choices.

The costs are only a guide based on our own research. You may be able to find things more cheaply, or you may want things that we haven't included.

expense.name: Nursery furniture
expense.reviewtext:
We've included a changing unit and a small chest of drawers. These could cost from £100 to £1000.

It' s tempting to fully furnish the nursery but it may be better to wait and see what items of furniture you' ll actually need. Talk to friends and family to see what they did and didn' t need when their baby was born. They may also be able to give or lend you furniture.

Check out parenting and auction websites — many parents recycle unwanted baby things so you may be able to get some bargains.

Use the slider to choose a level of spend, from budget to luxury. We' ll work out the total cost based on your choices.

The costs are only a guide based on our own research. You may be able to find things more cheaply, or you may want things that we haven't included.

expense.name: Buggy
expense.reviewtext:
We've included a buggy suitable from birth with a rain cover, foot muff and parasol. This could cost from £80 to £600.

If you buy a travel system you won't need a separate buggy. Most include either a carrycot or car seat and a pushchair, and are suitable for babies from birth. Talk to friends and family — they may be able to give or lend you baby equipment.

Check out parenting and auction websites — many parents recycle unwanted baby things so you may be able to get some bargains.

Use the slider to choose a level of spend, from budget to luxury. We'll work out the total cost based on your choices.

The costs are only a guide based on our own research. You may be able to find things more cheaply, or you may want things that we haven't included.

item.name: Buggy
item.description: You also have the option of a travel system which includes the buggy and car seat or you may like the option of a baby carrier which cost from £20

expense.name: Baby car seat
expense.reviewtext:
We've included a baby car seat suitable for up to around 9 months old. This could cost from £80 to £220.

Talk to friends and family — they may be able to give or lend you baby equipment. Check out parenting and auction websites — many parents recycle unwanted baby things so you may be able to get some bargains.

Remember you shouldn't buy a second-hand car seat unless you're sure it's never been involved in a road traffic accident.

If you buy a travel system you won't need a separate car seat. Most include either a carrycot or car seat and a pushchair, and are suitable for babies from birth.

Use the slider to choose a level of spend, from budget to luxury. We'll work out the total cost based on your choices.

The costs are only a guide based on our own research. You may be able to find things more cheaply, or you may want things that we haven't included.

expense.name: Child car seat
expense.reviewtext:
We've included a second stage car seat suitable from around 9 months to 4 years old. This could cost from £100 to £300.

Talk to friends and family — they may be able to give or lend you baby equipment. Check out parenting and auction websites — many parents recycle unwanted baby things so you may be able to get some bargains.

Remember you shouldn't buy a second-hand car seat unless you're sure it's never been involved in a road traffic accident.

Use the slider to choose a level of spend, from budget to luxury. We'll work out the total cost based on your choices.

The costs are only a guide based on our own research. You may be able to find things more cheaply, or you may want things that we haven't included.

expense.name: Other equipment
expense.reviewtext:
We've included:

  • High chair/booster seat : from £20 to £155
  • Baby monitor : from £25 to £175
  • Stair gate : from £15 to £100
  • Baby rocker/bouncer : from £15 to £130
  • Baby bath, toiletries and towels : from £30 to £100

You can buy a lot of equipment for your baby, but think about what you'll need — and what you can afford. Talk to friends and family to see what they did and didn't need when their baby was born. They may also be able to give or lend you clothes or equipment.

Check out parenting and auction websites — many parents recycle unwanted baby things so you may be able to get some bargains.

Use the slider to choose a level of spend, from budget to luxury. We'll work out the total cost based on your choices.

The costs are only a guide based on our own research. You may be able to find things more cheaply, or you may want things that we haven't included.

item.name: Other equipment
item.description: We've inluded  high chair, baby monitor, a stair gates, baby bath and toilertires, baby bouncer or rocker

expense.name: Clothing
expense.reviewtext:
For each age group (newborn, 3, 6, 9 and 12 months), we've included:

  • Sleepsuits and vests : from £125 to £800 in total
  • Day wear (tops, trousers, knitwear etc) : from £250 to £1,000 in total
  • Outerwear (snowsuit, coat etc) : from £90 to £200 in total

Babies grow very quickly, so 'newborn' clothes may only last you a couple of weeks. If your baby has a bigger than average birth weight, 'newborn' may be too small.

Talk to friends and family and see if they can give or lend you clothes and equipment. Ask them what they did and didn't need when their baby was born.

Use the slider to choose a level of spend, from budget to luxury. We'll work out the total cost based on your choices.

The costs are only a guide based on our own research. You may be able to find things more cheaply, or you may want things that we haven't included.

item.name: Clothing
item.description: Includes basic rompers suits, vests per age group, 5 outfits per age group, snow suit or coat equivalent

expense.name: Nappies
expense.reviewtext:
We've assumed you'll be using disposable nappies. We've included:

  • 5 packs of 36 nappies each month — 2,160 nappies in total — costing from £230 to £360
  • Nappy sacks, wipes and creams : £100

You will need more nappies in baby's first months (a newborn will need on average 9 nappies a day) and less as they get older.

Use the slider to choose a level of spend, from budget to luxury. We'll work out the total cost based on your choices.

There's little difference in the cost of using reusable or disposable nappies in the first year. But re-usable nappies may save you money from the second year onwards and with subsequent children, when the initial costs are recouped. You can buy starter kits of reusable nappies to try out, at a small cost, to see if they're right for you.

The costs are only a guide based on our own research. You may be able to find things more cheaply, or you may want things that we haven't included.

item.name: Nappies
item.description: Figures need working out based on extra data. Opting for slider prices quoting price of various disposables from value to premium brands. Text will explain basis facts about using reusable nappies and set up cost of this method.

expense.name: Milk
expense.reviewtext:
How you feed your baby is a personal decision. Use the slider to choose how you want to feed your baby, from breast only to bottle only.

Remember, even if you breast feed to start with, you may want to move on to bottle feeding later, for example if you go back to work or study. If so, you can use the slider to show how much of baby's first year you plan to breast feed for. We'll work out the total cost based on your choices.

If you bottle feed from birth we've assumed that you'll need to spend £400 on formula milk. We've assumed that breast milk is free.

For both breast and bottle feeding, we've included a cost of £50 to cover the cost of equipment such as bottles and a steriliser. If you're breastfeeding you may need lanolin ointment, a hot/cold gel pack, nursing bras and pads,and a breast pump.

There are lots of additional extras which can cut time and make meal times while travelling easier. Bottle warming flasks, microwave sterilising bags, thermal bottle carry packs, sterilising wipes and solution are nice to have if you can afford it, but not essential.

The costs are only a guide based on our own research. You may be able to find things more cheaply, or you may want things that we haven't included.

item.name: Milk
item.description: The cost of formula or breast includes sterilser and bottles. No details table just text on formula (to be supplied with copy) 0 formula =100% breast feeding. Figure for calculator is figure highlighted in green.

expense.name: Food
expense.reviewtext:
You can usually start your baby on solids at around six months old — usually with baby rice mixed with breast milk or formula. Babies typically don't eat a lot of solid foods right away — they're an addition to their diet.

You can mash food that you've prepared for yourself which will add only a small cost to your shopping bill. Alternatively if you're using only shop-bought food, we've assumed that from 6 months, you use 3 jars a day costing £420 in total.

In both cases, we've included a cost of £100 to cover snacks and equipment such as bibs and baby cups, bowls and spoons.

Use the slider to show how much of baby's food you'll make yourself and how much will be bought. We'll work out the total cost based on your choices.

The costs are only a guide based on our own research. You may be able to find things more cheaply, or you may want things that we haven't included.

item.name: Food
item.description: Work on  the same principle as formula and breast slider. Homemade cost of £0 at one end and 100% prepared food at the other. Use total highlighted in green.
